description: Comparison data from Adams (2024) police executive study and Adams et al. (2025) public opinion study

executive.citation: Adams, I. T. (2024). Fuck: The Police. Police Quarterly, 28(1), 10986111241241750.
executive.note: Survey of active police executives on profanity norms

public.citation: Adams, I. T., Olson, M., James, L., Tregle, B., & Boehme, H. M. (2025). Fuck: Public Opinion. Police Quarterly, 10986111251357508.
public.note: Nationally representative survey weighted to U.S. demographics

regressionCoefficients.description: Coefficients from Table 3 of Adams et al. (2025), showing effects relative to Self/Neutral baseline
regressionCoefficients.note: Add coefficients to baseline (Self/Neutral intercept) to get predicted means for each condition

demographicEffects.description: Demographic moderators from Table 4 of Adams et al. (2025)
demographicEffects.note: These show how demographic groups differ from the reference category

keyFindings.title: Target matters most
keyFindings.description: Public-directed profanity receives substantially harsher judgments than colleague- or self-directed profanity, regardless of intent.

keyFindings.title: Intent has smaller effects
keyFindings.description: While derogatory intent worsens judgments and positive intent improves them, these effects are much smaller than target effects.

keyFindings.title: Executives vs. Public
keyFindings.description: Police executives tend to be slightly more accepting of profanity directed at self or colleagues, but similarly condemn public-directed profanity.

keyFindings.title: Demographic differences
keyFindings.description: Women, non-white respondents, and Democrats tend to rate police profanity as less appropriate; Republicans and higher-income respondents tend to be more accepting.
